report.report_text:
[Report de-identified (Safe-harbor compliant) by De-ID v.6.22.07.0]
CONSULTATION REPORT City Hospital New York, NY 10001 __________________________________________________
Jane Doe 987654321 987654321 B3C/2 ___________________________________________________
DATE OF CONSULTATION: May 24, 2024
CONSULTING PHYSICIAN: Dr. Michael Thompson, M.D.
ATTENDING PHYSICIAN: Dr. Laura Davis, M.D.
REQUESTING PHYSICIAN: Dr. Sarah Lee, M.D.
CARDIOLOGY
REASON FOR CONSULTATION Chest pain and shortness of breath.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS This is a 68-year-old African American woman with a history of coronary artery disease and hypertension. She was admitted with severe chest pain radiating to her left arm, accompanied by shortness of breath and diaphoresis. She reports that the pain started suddenly while she was at rest. She denies any recent physical exertion or emotional stress. She has been given aspirin and nitroglycerin in the emergency room.
PAST MEDICAL & SURGICAL HISTORY 1. Coronary artery disease. 2. Myocardial infarction two years ago. 3. Hypertension. 4. Gastroesophageal reflux disease. 5. Hypercholesterolemia. 6. Cholecystectomy.
FAMILY HISTORY Her father had a history of myocardial infarction. No known history of stroke or diabetes in the family.
SOCIAL HISTORY The patient is a retired teacher. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. She lives alone and is independent in her daily activities.
CURRENT MEDICATIONS 1. Aspirin 81 mg daily. 2. Metoprolol 50 mg twice daily. 3. Atorvastatin 40 mg daily. 4. Lisinopril 10 mg daily. 5. Omeprazole 20 mg daily. 6. Nitroglycerin 0.4 mg sublingually as needed for chest pain.
LABORATORY DATA WBC count 8.2, hemoglobin 12.5, hematocrit 38.0, platelet count 250. Sodium 140, potassium 4.2, chloride 103, bicarbonate 24, BUN 18, creatinine 0.9. Troponin I elevated at 0.8 ng/mL. Electrolytes within normal limits. EKG shows ST-segment depression in leads II, III, and aVF.
DIAGNOSTICS Chest x-ray shows no acute infiltrates. Echocardiogram reveals mild left ventricular hypertrophy with an ejection fraction of 55%.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION VITALS: Blood pressure is 145/85, temperature 36.7, pulse 78, respiratory rate 18. HEENT: Normocephalic/atraumatic, no JVD. CHEST: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles. CARDIOVASCULAR: S1 and S2 present, no S3 or S4, regular rhythm. ABDOMEN: Soft, non-tender, no hepatosplenomegaly. EXTREMITIES: No edema, pulses 2+ bilaterally. NEUROLOGIC: Alert and oriented, no focal deficits.
ASSESSMENT/RECOMMENDATIONS 1. Acute coronary syndrome. a) Continue aspirin and beta-blocker therapy. b) Initiate heparin drip and clopidogrel. c) Prepare for coronary angiography. d) Monitor cardiac enzymes serially.
2. Hypertension. a) Adjust antihypertensive regimen as needed.
3. Gastroesophageal reflux disease. a) Continue omeprazole therapy.
4. Hypercholesterolemia. a) Continue statin therapy.
Thank you for allowing us to assist in the care of this patient. Please do not hesitate to contact us for any further assistance.
__________________________________ Dr. Michael Thompson, M.D.
Dict: May 24, 2024 14:00:00 Tran: May 24, 2024 14:30:00 MT
R: May 24, 2024 15:00:00/mt
Dr. Laura Davis, M.D., <Attending> Dr. Michael Thompson, M.D.
